title-group.subtitle: The Human Ecology and Political Economy of Coal Consumption

article-meta.aff: 1University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Coal and the Environment

abstract.p: Structural human ecology, ecological modernization theory, and international political economy perspectives are engaged to assess the extent to which coal consumption is influenced by various demographic factors, socioeconomic characteristics, and international relationships. Results of panel analyses for a sample of 66 countries from 1990 to 2005 indicate that both total population size and economic development increase levels of coal consumption. Additional findings suggest that export-oriented manufacturing increases coal consumption in developing nations but not in developed nations. The authors conclude by reflecting on the theoretical implications of the study and the policy relevance of the results for dealing with the human causes and consequences of climate change.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The transition from the Holocene to the Anthropocene took place in the late 18th century, around the time of the Industrial Revolution.1 It marks a distinct moment in history when humanity became the main driver of rapid changes in the earth system (Crutzen, 2002; Steffan, Crutzen, & McNeil, 2007). A new economic system continued to emerge, powered by coal, which helped increase the scale and intensity of industrial operations. Coal remains at the heart of modern history, as it is an integral source of power for industry and for household use throughout the world (Freese, 2003; Malm, 2012b).2 Although other sources of energy (e.g., solar) have experienced increased use, in 2005 coal supplied approximately 40% of the electricity in the world (Smil, 2008).

Recent scientific studies indicate that anthropogenic forces are disrupting global ecosystems and transgressing the “planetary boundaries” that support human civilization (Rockström et al., 2009; Vitousek, Mooney, Lubchenko, & Melilo, 1997). Human activities are responsible for the observed warming of the atmosphere, increasing the threat of abrupt climate change (Hansen et al., 2008; Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007). The burning of coal is one of the major anthropogenic sources of carbon dioxide emissions. As a result, coal consumption patterns throughout global society will greatly influence the accumulation of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Here the political-economic organization of societies and their interrelationships remain at the nexus of climate change. Macro-level perspectives within environmental sociology consider how specific social structures and relationships at multiple scales shape the human dimensions of environmental change. Drawing from various perspectives, including structural human ecology and international political economy, we analyze a cross-national panel data set to assess the effects of population growth, economic development, and world-economic organization on coal consumption.

sec.title: Structural Human Ecology and Environmental Impacts
sec.p: Human ecologists explain that society is embedded within a larger ecological complex, composed of reciprocal relationships between population, organizations, environment, and technology (Duncan, 1961; Duncan & Schnore, 1959; Dunlap & Catton, 1979). Too often sociological inquiry fails to consider that humans are dependent and part of the larger environment, which includes natural limits (Catton, 1980; York & Mancus, 2009). At the same time, Otis Dudley Duncan (1964, p. 48) explained that “one of the central preoccupations of human ecology” is social organization given the centrality it plays in human society. He pointed out that the growth of all organisms and societies requires the expenditure of energy. Furthermore, the structural organization of society influences the flow of material resources, as well as the rate and scale of energy consumption. Preindustrial societies generally relied on limited supplies of biomass for energy, which in part restricted the forms of social organization and constrained the overall energy demands (Harvey, 1996; Smil, 1994). Industrial societies, employing steam engines, greatly increased the consumption of coal (and energy in general) and the productive capacity of manufacturing.

The structural human ecology approach analyzes the relationships of interchange between social systems and the natural environment. It assesses the social structural drivers of environmental transformations. It also recognizes that ecological factors, such as biogeography, play an important role in shaping how social structures and organizations affect the natural environment (e.g., Dietz & Rosa, 1994; Dietz, Rosa, & York, 2007, 2009). Structural human ecology is also one of the main traditions within environmental sociology that provides an explicit focus on population–environment relationships.

Using a structural human ecology framework, the Stochastic Impacts by Regression on Population, Affluence, and Technology (STIRPAT) research program was created to operationalize the concept of human ecosystem and to offer a set of analytical tools to understand anthropogenic impacts (York, Rosa, & Dietz, 2003a, 2003c). The STIRPAT model is a reformulation of the IPAT formulation, where Impact = Population · Affluence · Technology. The IPAT approach does not “readily allow for non-monotonic or non-proportional effects from the driving effects,” whereas STIRPAT assesses the stochastic impacts by regression on the same measures (York et al., 2003c, p. 353). In a STIRPAT model, all continuous explanatory variables and the dependent variable are converted into logarithmic form. A conception of plasticity is introduced into this model to account for the fact that distinct “drivers generate impacts at different scales and at different rates” (York et al., 2003c, p. 353). Additional social, political, and cultural variables, if theoretically relevant, can be incorporated into this model. Beyond studying the impacts of population size, STIRPAT scholars also incorporate other demographic considerations, such as the age structure of nations and levels of urbanization (Dietz et al., 2007). This reformulated model can be used for hypothesis testing and is applicable at any spatial scale. It has been used to identify the principal driving forces of ecological degradation—such as population and economic growth—and their relative importance in cross-national analyses of the ecological footprint of nations and the carbon dioxide emissions of nations (Dietz et al., 2007; York et al., 2003a, 2003b).

This research has found that population size is a major and persistent factor determining the scale of environmental impact within nations. In other words, population growth increases energy consumption and the overall demands placed on nature (Mazur, 1994). Additionally, developed nations—when controlling for population—consume the bulk of resources and produce most of the pollution. Furthermore, affluence is the primary driver of greenhouse gas emissions (Dietz et al., 2007; Jorgenson & Birkholz, 2010; Jorgenson & Clark, 2010; Rosa, York, & Dietz, 2004; York et al., 2003b). In the analyses that follow, we consider the general premises of structural human ecology, as is consistent with the STIRPAT approach, that affluence (economic growth) and population (including the age structure of a population and percentage of the population that is urban) contribute to higher national-level rates of coal consumption.

sec.title: Ecological Modernization Theory and the Environmental Kuznets Curve Hypothesis
sec.p: Ecological modernization theory examines institutional and sociocultural changes associated with environmental concerns. This perspective arose in the 1980s as an attempt to account for the various forms of “environmental progress” and the efforts to pursue “sustainable development” within European nations. Social reform, environmental consciousness, technological development, and economic growth are seen as viable avenues for transforming production, developing “green” energy, and creating sustainable societies. It is proposed that these transformative processes are helping dematerialize the economy as relatively fewer natural resources are required to produce economic growth (Mol, 2001). Ecological modernization focuses on “how various institutions and social actors attempt to integrate environmental concerns into their everyday functioning, development, and relationships with others, including their relation with the natural world” (Mol, Spaargaren, & Sonnenfeld, 2009, p. 4).

Ecological modernization theorists propose that during the early stages of modernization, “economic rationality” served as the basis to evaluate social development and progress. Economic growth was privileged above other social concerns. As a result, the early stages of economic development generally involved high resources demands (such as the consumption of coal) and produced significant environmental degradation. In contrast, late modernity holds the potential for reflexivity and critical assessments, in part spurred on by social movements, the scientific community, government officials, and business leaders. Ecological modernization proponents suggest that an “ecological rationality” has increasingly taken root and is helping establish a sustainable path of development for human society. Thus, “the environmental crisis can and should be overcome by a further modernization of the existing institutions of modern society” (Spaargaren, 1997, p. 25). “Market dynamics and economic actors have a distinct role to play on the stage of environmental reform” as “global capitalist developments” help “trigger or mediate environmental innovations and reform” (Mol, 2002, p. 102). Social movements assert pressure on economic actors to make environmental improvements and to pursue green technological innovations. As a result, “Environmental improvement can go together with economic development via a process of delinking economic growth from natural resource inputs and outputs of emissions and wastes” (Mol, 1997, p. 141). In other words, “environmental reform can even result in an absolute decline in the use of natural resources and discharge of emissions, regardless of economic growth in financial or material terms (product output)” (Mol, 2002, p. 93).

It is suggested that ecological consciousness and environmental regulations encourage industries to pursue upstream environmental action, by employing “new technologies which prevent environmental pollution and deterioration from happening”—rather than relying on “end-of-pipe technology” (such as filters) that attempt to reduce pollution after it has already been created (Huber, 2009, p. 334). Technological advances and innovations serve as the foundation to green production by increasing energy and material efficiency. For example, “clean energy” replaces “dirty energy.” These transformations, it is proposed, will reduce the environmental burdens of society, by reducing the amount of pollution generated and the quantity of resources—such as coal—used in production. The ecological modernization argument is quite consistent with the environmental Kuznets curve hypothesis. Environmental economists propose that ecological impacts follow an inverted U-shaped curve in relation to economic development (Dinda, 2004; Grossman & Krueger, 1995). During the early stages of economic development, environmental impacts increase dramatically. Eventually, economic growth contributes to a desire for improvements in environmental quality and incentives to conserve environmental resources. Thus, environmental impacts reach a plateau and decrease at higher rates of growth. In this study, we employ appropriate measurements to consider the general premises of both ecological modernization theory and the environmental Kuznets curve hypothesis in relation to coal consumption.

sec.title: International Political Economy and the Environment
sec.p: Within environmental sociology, political-economy perspectives, such as the treadmill of production and world-systems analysis, examine how the structural organization of the global economy contributes to ecological degradation and the production of pollution (Burns, Davis, & Kick, 1997; Foster, Clark, & York, 2010; Roberts & Grimes, 2002; Schnaiberg, 1980; Schnaiberg & Gould, 1994). Capitalism is a system of generalized commodity production that must reproduce itself on an ever-larger scale (Baran & Sweezy, 1966; Burkett, 1999; Sweezy, 2004). During the Industrial Revolution, the burning of fossil fuels, such as coal, increased the mobility of capital, as factories could be built in locations removed from the rivers that had been previously used for power (Marx, 1976; Smil, 1994). Capital became increasingly dependent on the burning of fossil fuels to increase the scale and intensity of production to further the accumulation process (Clark & York, 2005; Foster, 2002). Given the growth imperative of the economic system, profits are reinvested to expand production, increasing “natural resource extraction,” the generation of pollution, and the disorganization of nature (Gould, Pellow, & Schnaiberg, 2004, p. 297; Schnaiberg, 1980).

Technological innovation is an integral part of contemporary economic development. It simplifies the labor process, allowing companies to automate production, move operations overseas, reduce costs, and/or produce new commodities. Within the coal industry, technological innovations, such as mountaintop removal techniques, displaced workers and increased the recovery of coal, while at the same time expanding the scale of environmental degradation (Austin & Clark, 2012; Bell & York, 2010; Fox, 1999). New technologies often improve the economic efficiency of industrial production by decreasing the amount of energy and/or raw materials used in the manufacturing of each unit. However, these technological innovations do not necessarily dematerialize society or reduce demands on nature, as suggested by the environmental Kuznets curve hypothesis and ecological modernization theory. Instead, savings that arise from efficient operations are generally reinvested to expand production. As a result, more units can be made within a specific amount of time. The increase in the scale of production often increases the total energy consumed, the amount of raw materials used, and the amount of greenhouse gases emitted (Foster, Clark, & York, 2010; Jorgenson & Clark, 2012; York, 2010a, 2010b).

Charles H. Anderson (1976, p. 153) argued that “nothing grows faster in the growth society than energy use,” given the diversification and expansion that takes place throughout all sectors of the capitalist economy. Likewise, the “Jevons paradox” suggests that greater efficiency in resource use, such as coal, may actually increase the overall consumption of that particular resource. Contemporary research indicates that economic expansion generally outstrips any gains made in energy efficiency (Clark & Foster, 2001; Jevons, 1906; Jorgenson, 2009; Polimeni, Mayumi, Giampietro, & Alcott, 2008). This relationship is made evident by the fact that the most economically developed nations tend to be more energy efficient. Yet these nations also “tend to consume the most resources and have the greatest environmental impacts” (York & Rosa, 2003, p. 281; see also Jorgenson, 2003; Jorgenson & Clark, 2011; York, Rosa, & Dietz, 2003a).

Political economists argue that capitalism, as the dominant economic system, consists of an integrated social system composed of interacting subsystems held together through conflicting forces and long-term historical processes (Baran, 1968; Chase-Dunn, 1998; Chase-Dunn & Grimes, 1995; Smith & White, 2005; Wallerstein, 1974). This arrangement—consisting of a hierarchical division of nations where economic, political, and military strength resides in the hands of the dominant capitalist nations—facilitates the unequal accumulation of capital between spheres within the global economy (Kentor, 2000). Economic growth in the Global North was, in part, achieved through the consumption of coal and other nonrenewable resources and the exploitation of distant lands (Burkett & Foster, 2006; Hornborg, 2011). Periodic shifts within the world-economic system influence development patterns, sites of production, the international division of labor, and the location of ecological degradation.

Philip McMichael (2008) indicates that a qualitative shift in international relations occurred in the late 1970s. Many less-developed countries experienced a deepening of foreign debt, which resulted in austerity measures developed by global governance and financial institutions. These austerity measures, such as structural adjustment programs, encouraged the governments of indebted countries to create more favorable conditions for foreign investors and transnational corporations and to focus on export-oriented manufacturing. At the heart of the austerity measures is the assumption that they will stimulate economic development to assist in debt repayment while increasing the overall well-being for domestic populations.

Within this “globalization project,” some developing countries experienced a period of economic growth due to an increase in industrial activity. These developing countries largely reoriented their economies to manufacturing export-oriented commodities, which increased the energy consumption of these nations. A number of push factors spurred this transference of manufacturing to the developing countries: rising labor costs in developed countries, transition to a service economy in developed economies, and the pressure of rising intercapitalist rivalries (Caporaso, 1981). More recently, this process has been facilitated by the accelerated development of information and communication technology, which allows for the geographic growth of commodity chains and the associated manufacturing processes (Milberg & Winkler, 2009).

The shift of early stages of manufacturing commodities to developing countries has created a “new international division of labor” that takes advantage of wage differentials within the global economic system (McMichael, 2008). Corporations, located primarily in developed countries, seek avenues to increase profits. Multinational companies offshore production and import manufactured goods from less-developed countries. These companies are able to focus on value-added processes such as marketing and brand design (Mahutga, 2006; Milberg & Winkler, 2009). Developing countries, therefore, have shifted their economic output toward manufacturing exports with the promise that doing so will generate more value and will result in the transfer of environmentally friendly technologies from the North to the South. However, the promise of yielding additional benefits from manufacturing more units has not panned out. Over time, income has not necessarily increased with an expansion in the manufacturing sector (Wade, 2004). Instead, developing countries confront a situation where they need to increase their rate of exportation to make a small profit (Roberts & Parks, 2007). Investment in manufacturing, then, has not evened out the development playing field and has helped maintain the hierarchically organized and fragmented global economy in which wealth is concentrated at the top in a small minority of countries (Gereffi, 2005). Instead, developing countries must expand their consumption of energy, including coal, in order to power export-oriented manufacturing operations (Jorgenson, 2012; Malm, 2012a).

In the analyses that follow, we assess the arguments of the above international political economy perspectives, with a particular focus on the effects of economic development and export-oriented manufacturing on coal consumption, and how the effects of the latter differ for the developed nations and developing nations.

sec.title: The Data Set
sec.p: We analyze a cross-national panel data set consisting of countries for which data are available for the dependent variable and all independent variables included in the analyses. At the time of this study, and to the best of our knowledge, the dependent variable is only available for a reasonable amount of countries for the years 1990 and 2005, where the measures are valid for cross-national and temporal comparisons, thereby restricting the analyses to these respective yearly observations and overall time period. The overall data set consists of two observations for 66 countries (N = 132). For some of the analyses, we restrict the data set to only the developed countries or only the less-developed countries in the overall data set.3 Developed countries are those in the upper quartile of the World Bank’s (2012) income quartile classification of countries, whereas less-developed countries are those that fall below the upper quartile. Within the overall data set, 23 of the 66 countries fall into the developed countries category (N = 46), whereas the other 43 countries are in the less-developed countries category (N = 86). Table 1 lists the countries included in the study.

sec.title: Model Estimation Technique
sec.p: We employ the “xtreg” suite of commands in Stata (Version 11) to estimate linear fixed effects panel regression models. This approach is one of the most commonly used longitudinal methods in the comparative social sciences, because it addresses the problem of heterogeneity bias (see Halaby, 2004). Heterogeneity bias in this context refers to the confounding effect of unmeasured time-invariant variables that are omitted from the regression models. To correct for heterogeneity bias, fixed effects models control for omitted variables that are time invariant but that do vary across cases, where cases in this study are the nations in the analyzed panel data set. The fixed effects approach provides a stringent assessment of the relationships between our predictors and the outcome given that the associations between them are estimated net of unmeasured between-country effects. We also include a dummy variable for 2005, which controls for potential unobserved heterogeneity that is cross-sectionally invariant within periods (i.e., period-specific intercept). The inclusion of period-specific intercepts is equivalent to modeling temporal fixed effects, and including both period-specific intercepts and unit-specific fixed effects is analogous to estimating a two-way fixed effects model.4 Two-way fixed effects models are ideal for hypothesis testing, providing more consistent and reliable results than other estimation techniques, such as random effects models (e.g., Allison, 2009).

With the xtreg suite of commands in Stata, the case-specific fixed effects are estimated with the within estimator, which involves a mean deviation algorithm for the dependent variable and each time-varying independent variable. This is also sometimes called the “conditional” method because it conditions out the coefficients for the fixed effects dummy variables (Allison, 2009).

To normalize the positively skewed distributions, prior to the panel analyses, we log (ln) the dependent variable and all independent variables except the dummy variable for the year 2005, which serves as the period-specific intercept. Such an approach is commonplace for methodological reasons (e.g., Dietz & Kalof, 2009), but it is also foundational for the STIRPAT structural human ecology orientation, particularly comparative-international research in the orientation that examines the human drivers of global environmental change and energy consumption (see stirpat.msu.edu for a thorough overview). This modeling technique, where all predictors and the outcome are converted into logarithmic form, is also known as a type of elasticity model. The coefficients of an elasticity model are easy to interpret for continuous variables, which applies here since all variables in the current study are continuous (with the exception of the period-specific intercept for the year 2005). The coefficient for each continuous independent variable is the estimated percentage change in the dependent variable associated with a 1% increase in the independent variable, controlling for other factors in the model.

sec.title: Dependent Variable
sec.p: The dependent variable is coal consumption, which specifically refers to the amount of primary energy consumed from primary and derived coal fuels. Data are reported in thousand tons of oil equivalent. We obtain these data from the World Resources Institute online Earthtrends database (see http://earthtrends.wri.org), which were gathered from the International Energy Agency (see http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp). Here, coal and coal products include all coal, both primary (including hard coal and lignite/brown coal) and derived fuels (including patent fuel, coke oven coke, gas coke, BKB, coke oven gas, blast furnace gas, and oxygen steel furnace gas). Peat is also included. Consumption equals indigenous production + imports − exports − energy delivered to international marine bunkers ± stock changes. The International Energy Agency refers to these data as Total Primary Energy Supply. Energy losses from transportation, friction, heat, and other inefficiencies are included in these totals.

sec.title: Independent Variables
sec.p: Consistent with the majority of prior cross-national research, we include gross domestic product per capita (GDP per capita) as a measure of a nation’s level of economic development. These data, which allow us to evaluate the assertions of various perspectives outlined in our literature review, are measured in 2000 constant U.S. dollars and obtained from the World Bank (2012).

We employ total population, measured in thousands, as an independent variable (World Bank, 2012). The measures of total population are based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship. Refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum are generally considered to be part of the population of their country of origin. Sociological research in the structural human ecology tradition consistently shows that population is a key driver of scale-level overall natural resource consumption, energy consumption, and greenhouse gas emissions (e.g., Dietz et al., 2007; Rosa et al., 2004; York, 2007; York et al., 2003b; see also Jorgenson & Clark, 2012) and that the association between various forms of environmental harms and population size is relatively large in magnitude and statistically time-invariant for both developed and less-developed countries (Jorgenson & Birkholz, 2010; Jorgenson & Clark, 2010).

We control for the relative size on nondependent populations, which specifically refers to the percentage of the total population of a given nation that is in the age group of 15 to 64 years. Population is based on the de facto definition of population as described above for the measure of total population (World Bank, 2012). Prior research in structural human ecology and related traditions shows that the relative size of nondependent populations is a primary contributor to growth in carbon dioxide emissions and overall fossil-fuel energy consumption (e.g., Jorgenson, 2012; York, 2007).

We include measures of urban population, which quantifies the percentage of a country’s population residing in urban areas. These data are gathered from the World Bank (2012). Prior research suggests that this form of social organization increases overall energy consumption (e.g., Clement & Schultz, 2011; Grimm et al., 2008; Jorgenson, Rice, & Clark, 2010; Rees & Wackernagel, 1996).
Manufacturing as percentage of GDP is included to control for the extent to which national economies focus on secondary sector activities. These data are also obtained from the World Bank (2012).

We include manufacture exports as percent total merchandise exports (World Bank, 2012) to control for the extent to which a nation has a secondary sector export-oriented economy. Here, manufactured goods comprise commodities in SITC Sections 5 (chemicals), 6 (basic manufactures), 7 (machinery and transport equipment), and 8 (miscellaneous manufactured goods), excluding Division 68 (nonferrous metals). In all tables and text, we refer to this variable as “manufacturing exports.”

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: Findings for the panel analyses are provided in Table 3. Model 1 is a simple baseline and consists of GDP per capita and total population as well as the dummy variable for the year 2005 and the unreported country-specific fixed effects. These predictors are included in all estimated models. Model 2 also includes nondependent population and urban population, whereas Model 3 also includes manufacturing as percent total GDP and manufacturing exports. Model 4 is the most fully saturated of the group and consists of all predictors in any of the preceding models as well as the dummy variable for the year 2005. Models 5 and 6 include GDP per capita, total population, manufacturing exports, the dummy variable for the year 2005, and the unreported country-specific fixed effects. Model 5 is estimated for the sample restricted to only less-developed countries, and Model 6 is estimated for the sample restricted to only developed countries. Given limited sample sizes and in the spirit or parsimony, these last two models included less predictor variables. We report unstandardized coefficients and corresponding robust standard errors for all predictors and constants in each model as well as rho and the values of r-square overall for each estimated model.

The results indicate that both level of economic development and total population positively affect coal consumption. The only exception is in Model 6, where the estimated coefficients for both these predictor variables are nonsignificant. However, this is not all that surprising given that this particular analysis is for the sample of only the developed countries, and the designation of the developed country category is determined by levels of economic development. More simply, there is limited variation in levels of economic development across the developed countries in the restricted sample. Such null findings are common in prior research on society/nature relationships restricted to nations in the Global North (e.g., Fisher & Freudenburg, 2004). The nonsignificant effect of population size is largely due to limited sample size, especially since the estimated coefficient is positive in value and is statistically significant at the .10 level for a one-tailed test.

The positive effects of GDP per capita and total population on coal consumption provide strong support for both structural human ecology and the political-economy perspectives. These findings are consistent with prior research that indicates that population growth is a driver of energy consumption, carbon dioxide emissions, and ecological degradation in general (Ehrlich & Holdren, 1971; Jorgenson & Clark, 2010; Rosa et al., 2004; Shi, 2003; York, 2007, 2010a, 2010b). Additionally, economic growth remains tied to growth in coal consumption and environmental demands in general. These findings lend support to the treadmill of production and world-systems perspectives within political economy, in which economic expansion increases the scale and intensity of the demands placed on natural resources and the general degradation of environmental conditions (Bunker & Ciccantell, 2005; Foster, Clark, & York, 2010; Jorgenson & Clark, 2009, 2011; Roberts & Grimes, 2002; Schnaiberg, 1980; Schnaiberg & Gould, 1994). Our results do not support the ecological modernization position that suggests that economic growth leads to the dematerialization—as far as coal consumption—of society, at least in cross-national contexts.

Turning to the additional population characteristics, the effects of both nondependent population and urban population are nonsignificant. Thus, in the context of coal consumption, it appears that the overall size of nations’ populations is of more relevance than their respective age distributions and relative levels of urbanization. However, we recognize the limitations of these measures as well as potential sampling challenges that could lead to these null findings. For example, the sample in this study excludes almost all the transition economy nations of Central and Eastern Europe, and contemporary research that focuses on those nations indicates that the relative size of nondependent populations is a strong predictor of anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions (Jorgenson, 2011; Jorgenson, Clark, & Giedraitis, 2012; York, 2008). Similarly, research on only E.U. countries indicates that nations with populations consisting of a larger proportion of elderly people consume higher levels of overall commercial energy (York, 2007). With regard to urbanization, the null findings could at least partly be a function of high collinearity between GDP per capita and our employed urban population measure, or perhaps as some have suggested, these two measures capture relatively similar underlying developmental characteristics of nations (Ehrhardt-Martinez, Crenshaw, & Jenkins, 2002). Furthermore, others have criticized this commonly used measure of urbanization since it does not capture the actual varying built environment conditions within nations, and such varying conditions could indeed shape energy consumption (e.g., Clement, 2010; Jorgenson et al., 2010).

With regard to the additional political-economic characteristics, the effect of manufacturing as percent total GDP is nonsignificant in all relevant models, whereas the effect of manufacturing exports is positive and statistically significant in Models 3, 4, and 5 but nonsignificant in Model 6. Thus, it appears that, in general, relative levels of manufacturing do not contribute to increases in coal consumption observable at the national level, but a focus on export-oriented manufacturing does, at least for less-developed countries.5 The latter finding is expected, given that the Global Governance Institutions have been encouraging for decades an array of policies to enhance world-economic integration to stimulate economic development. The “globalization project” (e.g., McMichael, 2008) prompted the Global South to open their countries to foreign investment and to expand export-oriented manufacturing industries, under the assumption of economic growth and upward mobility in the world economy (e.g., Gilpin, 2001; Mahutga, 2006; Mahutga & Smith, 2011). It is commonly argued and empirically substantiated (e.g., Jorgenson, 2007) that export-oriented manufacturing in developing nations is relatively more energy-intensive and less efficient concerning material and energy inputs as well as forms of waste, including industrial water pollution and forms of air pollution. Furthermore, energy-intensive and environmentally harmful export-oriented manufacturing in developing nations are tied to broader ecologically unequal relationships between nations in the Global North and the Global South, which allow for environmental load-displacements from the former to the latter (e.g., Hornborg, 2011; Jorgenson, 2012; Rice, 2007; Roberts & Parks, 2007). In other words, the Global North offloads part of its environmental burden to the Global South. Goods destined for the former are produced in the latter. This structural arrangement within the global economy has increased the coal consumption and carbon dioxide emissions of less-developed countries (Malm, 2012a).

We note that in additional unreported analyses of all three samples we include interactions between each of the six predictors and the dummy variable for the year 2005 to assess if their relationships with coal consumption changed from 1990 to 2005. This is an increasingly common form of investigation in longitudinal research on society/nature relationships (e.g., Jorgenson, 2012; Jorgenson & Birkholz, 2010; Jorgenson & Clark, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012; Jorgenson & Kuykendall, 2008). All interactions are nonsignificant, which suggests that the observed statistically significant relationships are relatively time-invariant in magnitude and do not appear to experience a relative decoupling through time. Furthermore, consistent with much work in environmental sociology and environmental economics, to test for a potential environmental Kuznets curve, we estimate models of all three samples that include the centered quadratic for GDP per capita. The quadratic is nonsignificant in all analyses, providing no empirical evidence of an environmental Kuznets curve for coal consumption. Last, in sensitivity analyses (available on request), we also control for total exports as percent GDP. Its effect is nonsignificant, and including it in estimated models does not substantively alter the reported findings.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The burning of coal is the leading source of carbon dioxide emissions, which is the primary greenhouse gas contributing to climate change. The coal question, namely coal consumption, is one of the looming issues that must be addressed for humanity to effectively confront the challenge presented by climate change. Through cross-national panel analyses of coal consumption from 1990 to 2005, this research suggests that population and economic growth both increase coal consumption, which by extension also act as drivers of climate change. Our findings also indicate that it is crucial to account for the structure of the world economy when considering the drivers of coal consumption. The “globalization project” has extended the international division of labor, as developing nations were actively encouraged to increase export-oriented manufacturing, which is also influenced by transnational corporations in the Global North outsourcing much of their production to sites within developing nations. This global shift in export-oriented production influences coal consumption within the borders of developing nations. A global perspective illuminates how the ecological burden of the Global North has, in part, been shifted to the Global South, as the latter has taken up the mantle of manufacturing goods for the global economy. The manufacturing of exports fits into a larger system of unequal transnational and international relations in which developing nations need to produce and export more goods in order to try to remain competitive with developed countries. A general implication of our findings is that policies to curtail climate change must address the roles that population size, economic growth, and world-economic relationships play in fueling coal consumption. More broadly, this research underscores the importance in considering both human-ecological and political-economic factors when assessing the human dimensions of environmental change at local, regional, and global levels.

For theoretical reasons, we include one model restricted to developed countries and another model limited to less-developed countries. Ecological modernization proposes that the dematerialization process should be more evident in developed countries where economic development is more advanced. Political–economic perspectives question the prospects of dematerialization under the growth imperative of capitalism, regardless of the society.
Results of Hausman tests for all models are statistically significant, indicating that fixed effects models are preferred over random effects models.

Elsewhere, we include the other explanatory variables (nondependent population, urban population, manufacturing as percentage GDP) in additional models restricted to only developed countries and only less-developed countries. Their estimated effects are all nonsignificant, and their inclusion does not substantively alter the reported findings of the reduced model for the two restricted samples.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Brett Clark is assistant professor of sociology and sustainability studies at the University of Utah. His research focuses on the political economy of global environmental change and the philosophy, history, and sociology of science. He has published articles in the American Journal of Sociology, Social Problems, Social Science Research, Theory and Society, Sociological Inquiry, The Sociological Quarterly, Organization & Environment, Population & Environment, Global Environmental Politics, International Journal of Comparative Sociology, and other scholarly publications.

Andrew K. Jorgenson is associate professor and director of graduate studies in sociology at the University of Utah. His comparative international research focuses on (1) the human dimensions of global and regional environmental change, (2) the public health impacts of pollution and urban slum prevalence in developing nations, and (3) the political economy of domestic income inequality. He is a member of the American Sociological Association’s Task Force on Sociology and Global Climate Change.
Daniel Auerbach is a graduate student at the University of Utah. His areas of research are environmental sociology, political economy, and sociology of science.
